words.definition: to officially end a law, system, or practice
words.example: The government voted to abolish the outdated tax system.

words.definition: completely unreasonable or illogical
words.example: It would be absurd to expect everyone to agree on this issue.

words.definition: to increase in speed or make something happen faster
words.example: The company plans to accelerate its expansion into new markets.

words.definition: able to be reached or obtained easily
words.example: The building is accessible to people with disabilities.

words.definition: to gradually gather or acquire more of something
words.example: Dust tends to accumulate in corners if not cleaned regularly.

words.definition: preventing success or development; harmful
words.example: Adverse weather conditions forced the cancellation of the event.

words.definition: to publicly support or recommend a particular cause or policy
words.example: Many experts advocate a balanced approach to climate change.

words.definition: the consequences or after-effects of a significant event
words.example: The country is still dealing with the aftermath of the natural disaster.

words.definition: to distribute resources or duties for a particular purpose
words.example: The committee will allocate funds to various departments.

words.definition: to make minor changes to improve a text or document
words.example: Parliament voted to amend the constitution.

words.definition: not identified by name; of unknown identity
words.example: The donor wishes to remain anonymous.

words.definition: based on random choice rather than reason or system
words.example: The decision seemed arbitrary and unfair to many employees.

words.definition: able to express ideas clearly and effectively
words.example: She is an articulate speaker who captivates her audience.

words.definition: to have ambitions to achieve something
words.example: Many young athletes aspire to compete in the Olympics.

words.definition: genuine; not a copy or fake
words.example: The museum only displays authentic artifacts.

words.definition: the right or condition of self-government
words.example: The region was granted greater autonomy in decision-making.

words.definition: legal status of being unable to repay debts
words.example: The company filed for bankruptcy after years of losses.

words.definition: a standard or point of reference for measuring quality
words.example: This study serves as a benchmark for future research.

words.definition: to be disloyal or reveal secrets
words.example: He felt betrayed when his friend shared his confidential information.

words.definition: very strange or unusual
words.example: The witness gave a bizarre account of what happened.

words.definition: to stop or bring to an end
words.example: The fighting ceased after the peace agreement was signed.

words.definition: to move continuously through a system or area
words.example: Rumours began to circulate about the company's financial problems.

words.definition: relating to a city or citizenship
words.example: It's our civic duty to vote in elections.

words.definition: a raw material or primary product that can be bought and sold
words.example: Oil is a valuable commodity in the global market.

words.definition: able to exist or work together without conflict
words.example: The new software is compatible with all major operating systems.

words.definition: having the necessary ability or skill
words.example: She is a competent manager who handles challenges well.

words.definition: capable of being imagined or understood
words.example: It's conceivable that technology will solve many current problems.

words.definition: following one after another without interruption
words.example: She won the championship for three consecutive years.

words.definition: prolonged public disagreement or heated discussion
words.example: The new policy sparked considerable controversy.

words.definition: based on what is generally done or believed
words.example: He rejected conventional methods in favour of innovation.

words.definition: the quality of being trusted and believed in
words.example: The scandal damaged the politician's credibility.

words.definition: to try to develop or improve something
words.example: She cultivated strong relationships with her colleagues.

words.definition: a lack or shortage of something essential
words.example: Vitamin D deficiency can cause various health problems.

words.definition: to become progressively worse
words.example: The patient's condition began to deteriorate rapidly.

words.definition: to depart from an established course
words.example: The pilot had to deviate from the flight path due to storms.

words.definition: to make or become less
words.example: The importance of this issue should not be diminished.

words.definition: to make information known publicly
words.example: The company refused to disclose details about the merger.

words.definition: a difference between things that should be the same
words.example: There was a discrepancy between the two reports.

words.definition: causing disturbance or problems
words.example: The student's disruptive behaviour interrupted the lesson.

words.definition: doubtful or questionable
words.example: The company's financial practices seem dubious.

words.definition: having the right to do or receive something
words.example: Only citizens are eligible to vote in national elections.

words.definition: difficult to find, catch, or achieve
words.example: Success in this field can be elusive without proper training.

words.definition: the act of compelling observance of a law or rule
words.example: Enforcement of traffic laws has become stricter recently.

words.definition: a thing with distinct and independent existence
words.example: The company operates as a separate legal entity.

words.definition: to destroy completely; to eliminate
words.example: The goal is to eradicate poverty within the next decade.

words.definition: to apply or bring to bear (influence, force, etc.)
words.example: She exerted considerable influence over the committee's decision.

words.definition: possible and practical to do easily
words.example: The project is technically feasible but requires significant funding.

words.definition: to rise and fall irregularly in number or amount
words.example: Stock prices fluctuate depending on market conditions.

words.definition: inspiring fear or respect through being large or powerful
words.example: The team faces a formidable opponent in the finals.

words.definition: to encourage the development of something
words.example: The programme aims to foster creativity in young people.

words.definition: forbidding or uninviting; very serious or gloomy
words.example: The economic forecast looks grim for the coming year.

words.definition: a conclusion that can be drawn from something
words.example: The implications of this discovery are far-reaching.

words.definition: something that motivates or encourages someone to do something
words.example: The company offers financial incentives for top performers.

words.definition: certain to happen; unavoidable
words.example: Change is inevitable in any growing organization.

words.definition: the basic physical systems and facilities of a country or region
words.example: The government plans to invest heavily in infrastructure development.

words.definition: the quality of being honest and having strong moral principles
words.example: She is known for her integrity and ethical standards.

words.definition: the state of being responsible for something; a financial obligation
words.example: The company's liabilities exceed its assets.

words.definition: belonging to or characteristic of a principal, dominant, or widely accepted group
words.example: Her views are outside mainstream political opinion.

words.definition: required by law or rules; compulsory
words.example: Wearing seatbelts is mandatory in most countries.

words.definition: so small or unimportant as to not be worth considering
words.example: The risk of side effects is negligible.

words.definition: famous or well-known for something bad
words.example: The area is notorious for high crime rates.

words.definition: no longer in use; out of date
words.example: Many traditional skills have become obsolete in the digital age.

words.definition: to counterbalance or compensate for something
words.example: The company's profits offset its earlier losses.

words.definition: very great in amount; overpowering
words.example: She received overwhelming support from her colleagues.

words.definition: continuing firmly in a course of action despite difficulty
words.example: His persistent efforts finally paid off.

words.definition: seeming reasonable or probable
words.example: Her explanation for being late sounded plausible.

words.definition: dealing with things in a practical way
words.example: We need a pragmatic approach to solve this problem.

words.definition: to formally forbid something by law or rule
words.example: Smoking is prohibited in all public buildings.

words.definition: likely or liable to suffer from something
words.example: Children are particularly prone to catching colds.

words.definition: to follow or chase; to continue with an activity
words.example: She decided to pursue a career in medicine.

words.definition: given or done in return; mutual
words.example: The two countries signed a reciprocal trade agreement.

words.definition: not or no longer needed or useful
words.example: Many workers were made redundant due to automation.

words.definition: unwilling and hesitant
words.example: She was reluctant to share her personal experiences.

words.definition: income generated from business activities or taxes
words.example: The company reported increased revenue this quarter.

words.definition: extremely thorough and careful
words.example: The research was subjected to rigorous testing.

words.definition: critical observation or examination
words.example: The proposal came under intense scrutiny from experts.

words.definition: showing no activity; not developing
words.example: The economy has been stagnant for several years.

words.definition: to support financially, typically through government funding
words.example: The government subsidizes public transportation.

words.definition: lower in rank or position
words.example: All other considerations are subordinate to safety.

words.definition: too long, slow, or dull; tiresome
words.example: Filing paperwork can be a tedious task.

words.definition: not certain or fixed; provisional
words.example: We made tentative plans to meet next week.

words.definition: to grow or develop well; to prosper
words.example: Children thrive in a supportive learning environment.

words.definition: never done or known before
words.example: The crisis created unprecedented challenges for businesses.

words.definition: able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions
words.example: She is a versatile performer who excels in multiple genres.

words.definition: capable of working successfully; feasible
words.example: Solar energy is now a viable alternative to fossil fuels.

words.definition: keeping careful watch for possible danger
words.example: Security guards must remain vigilant at all times.

words.definition: liable to change rapidly and unpredictably
words.example: The stock market has been highly volatile recently.

words.definition: found or distributed over a large area or number
words.example: There is widespread support for the new policy.

words.definition: to produce or provide; to give way under pressure
words.example: The research yielded important new findings.

words.definition: enthusiastic approval or praise
words.example: The film received critical acclaim at the festival.

words.definition: logical and consistent; clear and easy to understand
words.example: She presented a coherent argument for the proposal.

words.definition: to add to something in a way that enhances or improves it
words.example: The wine complements the flavour of the cheese perfectly.

words.definition: complete and including everything
words.example: The report provides a comprehensive overview of the situation.

words.definition: giving a lot of information clearly in few words
words.example: Please provide a concise summary of your findings.

words.definition: to comply with rules or standards; to behave according to accepted standards
words.example: All products must conform to safety regulations.

words.definition: to think about carefully; to consider
words.example: She is contemplating a career change.

words.definition: to deny the truth of a statement; to be contrary to
words.example: The evidence contradicts the witness's testimony.

words.definition: showing care and effort in one's work
words.example: She is a diligent student who never misses deadlines.

words.definition: to accept or support willingly and enthusiastically
words.example: The company has embraced new technology.

words.definition: to declare one's public approval of
words.example: Several celebrities have endorsed the campaign.

words.definition: a short extract from a film, broadcast, or piece of writing
words.example: The book contains excerpts from her personal diary.

words.definition: stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion
words.example: The contract contains explicit terms and conditions.

words.definition: showing great attention to detail; very careful
words.example: The scientist kept meticulous records of all experiments.

words.definition: A room used for sleeping in
words.example: My bedroom is on the second floor of the house.

words.definition: A room where food is prepared and cooked
words.example: She was cooking dinner in the kitchen when I arrived.

words.definition: A person who lives next to or near you
words.example: Our neighbours invited us for tea yesterday.

words.definition: A member of your family
words.example: All my relatives are coming to the wedding.

words.definition: The child of your aunt or uncle
words.example: My cousin lives in London with her family.

words.definition: The son of your brother or sister
words.example: My nephew is starting school next week.

words.definition: The daughter of your brother or sister
words.example: I bought a birthday present for my niece.

words.definition: A set of instructions for cooking food
words.example: I found a great recipe for chocolate cake online.

words.definition: One of the foods that you use to make a particular dish
words.example: Make sure you have all the ingredients before you start cooking.

words.definition: An occasion when food is eaten, or the food that is eaten
words.example: We usually have our main meal in the evening.

words.definition: A small amount of food eaten between meals
words.example: I had an apple as a snack this afternoon.

words.definition: Having a very pleasant taste
words.example: This soup is absolutely delicious!

words.definition: Recently made, picked, or prepared
words.example: I always buy fresh vegetables from the market.

words.definition: To cook food in boiling water
words.example: Boil the eggs for ten minutes.

words.definition: To cook food in hot oil or fat
words.example: Fry the onions until they are golden brown.

words.definition: Objects such as chairs, tables, and beds that you put in a room
words.example: We need to buy some new furniture for the living room.

words.definition: Making you feel relaxed and pleasant
words.example: This is a very comfortable sofa.

words.definition: Arranged neatly and in order
words.example: Please keep your room tidy.

words.definition: Untidy or dirty
words.example: My son's bedroom is always messy.

words.definition: To arrange or plan something
words.example: We need to organise a meeting for next week.

words.definition: To remove dirt from something
words.example: I clean the bathroom every Saturday.

words.definition: To clean something using water
words.example: Don't forget to wash your hands before dinner.

words.definition: To make clothes smooth using a heated iron
words.example: I need to iron my shirt for tomorrow.

words.definition: Clothes that need to be washed or are being washed
words.example: I do the laundry twice a week.

words.definition: A machine that washes plates, cups, and other kitchen items
words.example: Put the dirty plates in the dishwasher.

words.definition: Waste material or things that are no longer useful
words.example: Please take out the rubbish before you leave.

words.definition: A form of energy used to provide light and heat and to power machines
words.example: Our electricity bill was very high last month.

words.definition: A system for keeping a building warm
words.example: We need to turn on the heating because it's cold.

words.definition: Outside a building
words.example: The children love playing outdoors in summer.

words.definition: Inside a building
words.example: It's raining, so we'll have to stay indoors today.

words.definition: On or to an upper floor of a building
words.example: My office is upstairs on the third floor.

words.definition: On or to a lower floor of a building
words.example: Come downstairs and have breakfast with us.

words.definition: The act of travelling from one place to another
words.example: The journey to work takes about 30 minutes.

words.definition: To reach a place
words.example: What time does your train arrive in Manchester?

words.definition: To leave a place
words.example: The bus departs from the station at 8 o'clock.

words.definition: An arrangement to meet someone at a particular time
words.example: I have a doctor's appointment at three o'clock.

words.definition: To ask someone to come to an event
words.example: We're inviting all our friends to the party.

words.definition: Someone who is invited to visit or stay in your home
words.example: We're expecting guests for dinner tonight.

words.definition: To do something enjoyable for a special reason
words.example: We're celebrating my mother's birthday this weekend.

words.definition: To use something that belongs to someone else and then return it
words.example: Can I borrow your pen for a moment?

words.definition: To give something to someone for a short time
words.example: Could you lend me your umbrella until tomorrow?

words.definition: Helping you to do or achieve something
words.example: This book has lots of useful information.

words.definition: Quickly and unexpectedly
words.example: Suddenly, the lights went out and everything was dark.

words.definition: Without delay; at once
words.example: Please call me immediately when you arrive.

words.definition: Despite the fact that
words.example: Although it was raining, we went for a walk.

words.definition: Used to introduce a statement that contrasts with what was said before
words.example: The hotel was expensive. However, it was very comfortable.

words.definition: As stated by someone or shown by something
words.example: According to the weather forecast, it will rain tomorrow.

words.definition: Throughout the time of something
words.example: I fell asleep during the film.

words.definition: In the direction of something or someone
words.example: She walked towards the door and left the room.

words.definition: To have enough money to buy something
words.example: We can't afford a holiday this year.

words.definition: A room in a school where lessons take place
words.example: Our classroom has twenty desks and a large whiteboard.

words.definition: A person you work with in a profession or business
words.example: My colleague helped me finish the project on time.

words.definition: A list showing the times when classes or events are planned
words.example: Check your timetable to see when the maths lesson starts.

words.definition: To successfully complete a course of study at a university or college
words.example: She will graduate from university next summer.

words.definition: A person who is paid to work for someone else
words.example: The company has over 500 employees worldwide.

words.definition: A piece of work given to someone as part of their studies
words.example: We have to hand in our history assignment by Friday.

words.definition: To pay someone to work for you
words.example: The factory employs over 200 workers.

words.definition: An official record showing that you have finished a course or passed an exam
words.example: You need teaching qualifications to work in this school.

words.definition: To go to an event or place regularly
words.example: All students must attend the morning assembly.

words.definition: Money that you receive regularly for doing your job
words.example: His monthly salary is paid directly into his bank account.

words.definition: To study work that you have done in order to prepare for an exam
words.example: I need to revise my notes before the test tomorrow.

words.definition: A time or date by which something must be finished
words.example: The deadline for the project is next Monday.

words.definition: Having knowledge or skill from doing something for a long time
words.example: We are looking for an experienced teacher to join our team.

words.definition: A place in a school or workplace where people can buy and eat meals
words.example: The school canteen serves hot lunch every day.

words.definition: To formally ask for something, especially a job or a place at a university
words.example: Over fifty people applied for the position.

words.definition: A person who teaches at a university or college
words.example: The history lecturer gave an interesting talk about ancient Rome.

words.definition: To raise someone to a higher position or rank at work
words.example: She was promoted to manager after two years.

words.definition: The subjects that are taught in a school or the content of a course
words.example: Science is an important part of the school curriculum.

words.definition: To officially tell your employer that you are leaving your job
words.example: He decided to resign from his position last month.

words.definition: One of the periods into which the school year is divided
words.example: The autumn term begins in September.

words.definition: Having the training and ability to do something well
words.example: We need skilled workers for this technical job.

words.definition: A class at university in which a small group discusses a subject with a teacher
words.example: We have a seminar on British literature every Thursday.

words.definition: A formal meeting where someone is asked questions to decide if they are suitable for a job
words.example: I have a job interview at the bank tomorrow morning.

words.definition: An official document that proves you have completed a course or passed an exam
words.example: She received her certificate at the graduation ceremony.

words.definition: To remove someone from their job or to tell students they can leave
words.example: The teacher dismissed the class early because of the fire drill.

words.definition: A person who learns a skill by working for someone who is experienced
words.example: He started as an apprentice carpenter at the age of sixteen.

words.definition: To officially join a course or become a member of an institution
words.example: Students can enrol for evening classes starting in September.

words.definition: A type of job that needs special training or education
words.example: Teaching is a rewarding profession that requires patience.

words.definition: A formal test of knowledge or ability in a particular subject
words.example: The final examination will take place in June.

words.definition: Having the ability or qualities necessary for doing something
words.example: She is a very capable student who always completes her work.

words.definition: A section of a large organisation such as a school, university or business
words.example: The English department is on the second floor.

words.definition: To stop working permanently, usually because of age
words.example: My father retired from teaching at the age of sixty-five.

words.definition: A period of teaching given by a tutor to one student or a small group
words.example: I have a maths tutorial with my tutor on Wednesday afternoon.

words.definition: Working well and not wasting time or energy
words.example: She is a very efficient worker who always meets her targets.

words.definition: A qualification given for completing a university course
words.example: He has a degree in engineering from Cambridge University.

words.definition: To watch someone to make sure they do their work properly
words.example: The teacher supervises the students during break time.

words.definition: Money given to a student to help pay for their education
words.example: She won a scholarship to study at Oxford University.

words.definition: All the people who work for a particular organisation
words.example: The school staff includes thirty teachers and five assistants.

words.definition: To succeed in doing or getting something through effort
words.example: She achieved excellent results in all her examinations.

words.definition: A job or profession
words.example: Please write your name and occupation on the form.

words.definition: Relating to real situations and events rather than ideas
words.example: We have a practical science lesson in the laboratory today.

words.definition: The teacher who is in charge of a school
words.example: The headteacher announced the new school rules at assembly.

words.definition: To find new people to work in a company or join an organisation
words.example: The company is recruiting new graduates this summer.

words.definition: Connected with education, especially studying in schools and universities
words.example: Her academic performance has improved significantly this year.

words.definition: Time worked in addition to your normal working hours
words.example: He worked overtime last week to finish the important project.

words.definition: A room or building containing books that people can read or borrow
words.example: Students use the library to study quietly and borrow books.

words.definition: Having the duty of dealing with something or being in charge of someone
words.example: The team leader is responsible for managing the project.

words.definition: Not present in a place, especially at school or work
words.example: Three students were absent from class yesterday.

words.definition: A room or building used for scientific work and experiments
words.example: We conduct chemistry experiments in the laboratory every week.

words.definition: the place to which someone or something is going
words.example: Paris is a popular holiday destination for British tourists.

words.definition: suitcases and bags that you take with you when travelling
words.example: You can collect your luggage from the baggage reclaim area.

words.definition: a journey made by air, especially in a plane
words.example: Our flight to Rome was delayed by two hours.

words.definition: a person travelling in a vehicle, aircraft, or ship who is not driving or working on it
words.example: The bus can carry up to fifty passengers.

words.definition: the activity of visiting places of interest in a particular location
words.example: We spent the morning sightseeing in the old town.

words.definition: to travel around an area in order to learn about it
words.example: We decided to explore the countryside on foot.

words.definition: a person who is travelling or visiting a place for pleasure
words.example: Thousands of tourists visit the castle every year.

words.definition: a place to live or stay
words.example: The price includes flights and accommodation for seven nights.

words.definition: time when you are not working or studying and can relax
words.example: Most people now have more leisure time than their grandparents did.

words.definition: an activity that someone does for pleasure in their free time
words.example: My favourite hobby is collecting stamps from different countries.

words.definition: a group of objects gathered together
words.example: He has an impressive collection of old coins.

words.definition: the skill or activity of taking photographs
words.example: She's studying photography at college.

words.definition: a picture made using paint, or the activity of creating such pictures
words.example: There's a beautiful painting of a landscape on the wall.

words.definition: the activity of working in a garden
words.example: My mum spends every weekend gardening.

words.definition: a public performance of music
words.example: We went to a rock concert last Saturday night.

words.definition: the act of performing a play, concert, or other form of entertainment
words.example: The evening performance starts at 7.30 pm.

words.definition: the group of people watching or listening to a performance
words.example: The audience clapped loudly at the end of the show.

words.definition: a public display of works of art or items of interest
words.example: There's an exhibition of modern art at the gallery this month.

words.definition: a building where objects of historical or cultural interest are kept
words.example: We visited the science museum on our school trip.

words.definition: a large sports ground surrounded by seats for spectators
words.example: The football stadium can hold 60,000 people.

words.definition: a sports competition involving several teams or players
words.example: Our school won the tennis tournament this year.

words.definition: a person who trains and instructs a sports team or individual
words.example: Our new football coach is very experienced.

words.definition: a person who competes against another in a contest or game
words.example: Our opponents were much stronger than we expected.

words.definition: to gain points in a game or competition
words.example: She scored three goals in the match yesterday.

words.definition: to win a victory over someone in a battle or competition
words.example: We defeated the other team by five goals to two.

words.definition: success in defeating an opponent
words.example: The team celebrated their victory with champagne.

words.definition: a person who has defeated all opponents in a competition
words.example: She became the world champion at the age of nineteen.

words.definition: to take part in a race or competition
words.example: Athletes from over fifty countries will compete in the games.

words.definition: providing amusement or enjoyment
words.example: The film was very entertaining and made us laugh a lot.

words.definition: causing laughter and providing entertainment
words.example: He told us an amusing story about his travels.

words.definition: giving pleasure or satisfaction
words.example: We had a very enjoyable evening at the theatre.

words.definition: causing great enthusiasm and interest
words.example: It was an exciting match that kept us on the edge of our seats.

words.definition: making you feel calm and less worried
words.example: I find listening to music very relaxing after a long day.

words.definition: willing to take risks or try new experiences
words.example: She's quite adventurous and loves trying extreme sports.

words.definition: relating to the arts, customs, and achievements of a society
words.example: The city offers many cultural activities such as concerts and exhibitions.

words.definition: to take part in an activity or event
words.example: All students are encouraged to participate in school sports.

words.definition: to do an activity regularly to improve your skill
words.example: You need to practise the piano every day if you want to improve.

words.definition: to prepare for a sport or physical activity by exercising
words.example: The team trains three times a week.

words.definition: to entertain an audience by acting, singing, or dancing
words.example: The band will perform live at the festival.

words.definition: to provide someone with amusement or enjoyment
words.example: The clown entertained the children for an hour.

words.definition: to send out a programme on television or radio
words.example: The match will be broadcast live on Saturday afternoon.

words.definition: entertainment that is funny and makes people laugh
words.example: I prefer watching comedies to serious dramas.

words.definition: a film or television programme that gives facts about a real subject
words.example: We watched a documentary about wildlife in Africa.

words.definition: a book or film with an exciting story, often about crime
words.example: I'm reading a psychological thriller at the moment.

words.definition: an unusual, exciting, or dangerous experience
words.example: Their trip to the Amazon was a real adventure.

words.definition: the activity of staying in a tent on holiday
words.example: We go camping in the mountains every summer.

words.definition: the condition of your body and the degree to which it is free from illness
words.example: Regular exercise is important for good health.

words.definition: a disease or period of sickness
words.example: She missed school due to illness.

words.definition: an unpleasant physical sensation caused by injury or illness
words.example: I have a terrible pain in my back.

words.definition: physical harm or damage to someone's body
words.example: He suffered a knee injury during the football match.

words.definition: medical care given to help cure an illness or injury
words.example: She is receiving treatment for her condition at the hospital.

words.definition: a substance used to cure illness or relieve pain
words.example: Remember to take your medicine three times a day.

words.definition: a written instruction from a doctor for medicine
words.example: You'll need a prescription from your doctor to buy this medicine.

words.definition: a place where people receive medical treatment
words.example: There's a health clinic on the high street.

words.definition: to become well again after illness or injury
words.example: It took me two weeks to recover from the flu.

words.definition: to look at someone or something carefully to check their condition
words.example: The doctor examined my throat and said it was infected.

words.definition: physical activity that you do to stay healthy and strong
words.example: You should do at least thirty minutes of exercise every day.

words.definition: the food and drink that a person regularly consumes
words.example: A healthy diet should include plenty of fruit and vegetables.

words.definition: the process of eating the right kind of food for good health
words.example: Good nutrition is essential for children's development.

words.definition: the way in which two people or groups feel about and behave towards each other
words.example: She has a good relationship with her colleagues.

words.definition: a close relationship between friends
words.example: Their friendship has lasted for over twenty years.

words.definition: a person you are married to or in a romantic relationship with
words.example: She lives with her partner and their two children.

words.definition: a brother or sister
words.example: Do you have any siblings or are you an only child?

words.definition: a person in your family who lived a long time ago
words.example: My ancestors came from Italy in the 19th century.

words.definition: to become the husband or wife of someone in a legal ceremony
words.example: They're planning to marry next summer.

words.definition: to legally end your marriage
words.example: They decided to divorce after ten years of marriage.

words.definition: to disagree with someone in an angry way
words.example: My parents often argue about money.

words.definition: to stop being angry with someone who has done something wrong
words.example: I found it hard to forgive him for lying to me.

words.definition: to believe that someone is honest and will not harm you
words.example: I trust her completely with my secrets.

words.definition: to give help or encouragement to someone
words.example: My family has always supported me in my decisions.

words.definition: to feel interest or concern about something or someone
words.example: She really cares about her students.

words.definition: to admire someone because of their qualities or achievements
words.example: I respect him for his honesty and hard work.

words.definition: a strong feeling such as love, fear, or anger
words.example: She was overcome with emotion when she heard the news.

words.definition: a strong feeling of being annoyed or upset
words.example: He couldn't hide his anger when he discovered the truth.

words.definition: a feeling of great happiness
words.example: She jumped for joy when she passed her exam.

words.definition: the feeling of being unhappy
words.example: There was a feeling of sadness in the room after the announcement.

words.definition: an unpleasant emotion caused by being aware of danger
words.example: Many people have a fear of flying.

words.definition: an unexpected or astonishing event or fact
words.example: We're planning a surprise party for her birthday.

words.definition: to feel anxious or concerned about something
words.example: Don't worry, everything will be fine.

words.definition: a state of mental or emotional strain caused by difficult circumstances
words.example: She's been under a lot of stress at work recently.

words.definition: a feeling of worry or nervousness
words.example: He suffers from anxiety before exams.

words.definition: feeling pleased about something you have done or are connected with
words.example: I'm very proud of my daughter's achievements.

words.definition: feeling angry or unhappy because someone has something you want
words.example: She was jealous of her sister's success.

words.definition: unhappy or disappointed about something
words.example: He was very upset when his dog died.

words.definition: worried or anxious about something
words.example: I always feel nervous before giving a presentation.

words.definition: feeling sure about your abilities or that something will happen
words.example: She's very confident about passing the test.

words.definition: sad because you are alone and lack friends or company
words.example: She felt lonely after moving to a new city.

words.definition: feeling or showing thanks to someone
words.example: I'm very grateful for all your help.

words.definition: sad because something has not happened or is not as good as expected
words.example: He was disappointed when he didn't get the job.

words.definition: feeling embarrassed or guilty about something
words.example: She felt ashamed of her behaviour at the party.

words.definition: no longer feeling worried or anxious
words.example: I was relieved to hear that the operation was successful.

words.definition: A particular way of considering or regarding something; a point of view
words.example: From my perspective, the proposal has several advantages.

words.definition: A thing that is accepted as true or certain to happen, without proof
words.example: Your argument is based on a false assumption.

words.definition: A conception or belief about something
words.example: She has some romantic notions about country life.

words.definition: The attitude of a person or organisation towards something; a standpoint
words.example: The government's stance on immigration has changed.

words.definition: To lessen the effectiveness, power, or ability of something
words.example: His constant criticism undermined her confidence.

words.definition: To show or prove to be right or reasonable
words.example: How can you justify spending so much money?

words.definition: To accept or admit the existence or truth of something
words.example: She acknowledged that the project had failed.

words.definition: To make a statement or situation less confused and more comprehensible
words.example: Could you clarify what you mean by that?

words.definition: To give special importance or prominence to something in speaking or writing
words.example: The report emphasises the need for better education.

words.definition: To suggest or indicate something without stating it directly
words.example: Are you implying that I'm lying?

words.definition: Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical existence
words.example: Truth and beauty are abstract concepts.

words.definition: Based on or influenced by personal feelings or opinions
words.example: Beauty is subjective and varies from person to person.

words.definition: Giving rise or likely to give rise to controversy or public disagreement
words.example: The film deals with controversial political issues.

words.definition: Open to more than one interpretation; not having one obvious meaning
words.example: Her answer was deliberately ambiguous.

words.definition: Forming a necessary base or core; of central importance
words.example: Fresh air is fundamental to good health.

words.definition: Actually supporting the intended point; legally or officially acceptable
words.example: That's a valid point that we should consider.

words.definition: Evoking interest or attention in a powerfully irresistible way
words.example: She made a compelling case for reform.

words.definition: A confident and forceful statement of fact or belief
words.example: His assertion that he was innocent proved to be false.

words.definition: A previous statement or proposition from which another is inferred
words.example: The film is based on the premise that technology will save us.

words.definition: A supposition or proposed explanation made on limited evidence
words.example: Scientists tested their hypothesis through experiments.

words.definition: The action of thinking about something in a logical way
words.example: I don't follow your reasoning on this matter.

words.definition: The forming of a theory without firm evidence
words.example: There has been much speculation about his resignation.

words.definition: Done consciously and intentionally
words.example: It was a deliberate attempt to mislead the public.

words.definition: Existing as a natural or essential part of something
words.example: There are inherent risks in any business venture.

words.definition: Believing that people are motivated purely by self-interest
words.example: She has a cynical view of human nature.

words.definition: Based on or in accordance with reason or logic
words.example: There must be a rational explanation for this.

words.definition: Prejudice in favour of or against one thing compared with another
words.example: The newspaper has a clear political bias.

words.definition: General agreement among a group of people
words.example: There is a growing consensus that the policy has failed.

words.definition: A detailed analysis and assessment of something
words.example: She wrote a critique of modern art.

words.definition: A disagreement or argument
words.example: The dispute between the two countries continues.

words.definition: A comparison between one thing and another for explanation
words.example: He drew an analogy between the brain and a computer.

words.definition: A fundamental truth or proposition serving as a foundation
words.example: I agree with you in principle, but not in practice.

words.definition: To become aware of something through the senses; to interpret
words.example: How do you perceive the current situation?

words.definition: To form an idea of the amount or value of something
words.example: We need to evaluate the effectiveness of the programme.

words.definition: To arrive at a conclusion by reasoning
words.example: From the evidence, we can deduce that he was lying.

words.definition: To communicate or make known an idea or feeling
words.example: She conveyed her disappointment through her expression.

words.definition: To strengthen or support an idea or feeling
words.example: This evidence reinforces my belief that he is innocent.

words.definition: To prove a statement or theory to be wrong or false
words.example: The lawyer refuted all the accusations against her client.

words.definition: Of considerable importance, size, or worth
words.example: They made substantial changes to the proposal.

words.definition: Very great or intense; showing great knowledge or insight
words.example: The book had a profound effect on her thinking.

words.definition: Suggested though not directly expressed
words.example: There was an implicit threat in his words.

words.definition: Unable to bend or be forced out of shape; not flexible
words.example: The company has a rigid hierarchy.

words.definition: Relating to moral principles or the branch of knowledge dealing with these
words.example: The experiment raises serious ethical questions.

words.definition: Conforming to the law or to rules; able to be defended with logic
words.example: That's a legitimate concern that should be addressed.

words.definition: A seemingly absurd or contradictory statement which may be true
words.example: It's a paradox that in a wealthy country, many people are poor.

words.definition: Behaviour showing high moral standards; a good quality
words.example: Patience is a virtue that not everyone possesses.

words.definition: The intrinsic nature or most important quality of something
words.example: Time is of the essence in this matter.

words.definition: Preconceived opinion not based on reason or experience
words.example: We must fight against racial prejudice.

words.definition: A sceptical attitude; doubt about the truth of something
words.example: His claims were met with considerable scepticism.

words.definition: The ability to understand and share the feelings of another
words.example: She showed great empathy towards the victims.

words.definition: A firmly held belief or opinion
words.example: She spoke with conviction about the need for change.

words.definition: A person's natural tendency or urge to act in a particular way
words.example: He showed little inclination to help with the work.

words.definition: The capacity to gain an accurate and deep understanding
words.example: The book provides valuable insights into human behaviour.

words.definition: To regard something as being caused by someone or something
words.example: She attributes her success to hard work and luck.

words.definition: To recognise or find out with difficulty
words.example: It's difficult to discern any pattern in these figures.

words.definition: To regard as probable; to expect or predict
words.example: We anticipate that prices will rise next year.

words.definition: To form a theory without firm evidence
words.example: Scientists can only speculate about life on other planets.

words.definition: To develop or present a theory or idea in detail
words.example: Could you elaborate on your proposal?

words.definition: To make two apparently conflicting things compatible
words.example: It's difficult to reconcile his behaviour with his beliefs.

words.definition: The feeling that a person or thing is worthless or beneath consideration
words.example: She looked at him with contempt.

words.definition: A statement or assertion that expresses a judgement or opinion
words.example: The proposition that all men are equal is debatable.

words.definition: A view or opinion that is held or expressed
words.example: Public sentiment has turned against the government.

words.definition: Having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned
words.example: She seemed indifferent to his suffering.

words.definition: In a way that does not vary; in every case or occasion
words.example: He has consistently denied the allegations.

words.definition: Difference in size, degree, or circumstances; lack of equality
words.example: There is growing inequality between rich and poor.

words.definition: Unjust treatment of different categories of people
words.example: Racial discrimination is illegal in this country.

words.definition: The action or process of combining things to form a whole
words.example: The integration of immigrants into society takes time.

words.definition: The state of being diverse; variety
words.example: The school celebrates cultural diversity.

words.definition: A widely held but fixed and oversimplified image of a type of person
words.example: The film challenges traditional gender stereotypes.

words.definition: Valued objects and qualities such as historic buildings and cultural traditions
words.example: We must preserve our cultural heritage for future generations.

words.definition: An established organisation, especially one dedicated to education or culture
words.example: The BBC is a national institution.

words.definition: The health, happiness, and fortunes of a person or group
words.example: The government is responsible for the welfare of its citizens.

words.definition: The state of being extremely poor
words.example: Millions of people live in poverty.

words.definition: The state of being prosperous; success or wealth
words.example: The country enjoyed a period of economic prosperity.

words.definition: A category of artistic composition characterised by a particular style
words.example: Science fiction is my favourite film genre.

words.definition: A work of outstanding artistry or skill
words.example: The painting is considered a masterpiece of Renaissance art.

words.definition: To show or represent by a drawing, painting, or other art form
words.example: The painting depicts a rural scene from the 19th century.

words.definition: To depict someone or something in a work of art or literature
words.example: The film portrays him as a hero.

words.definition: A spoken or written account of connected events; a story
words.example: The film has a compelling narrative.

words.definition: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty
words.example: The building has great aesthetic appeal.

words.definition: Living or occurring at the same time; belonging to the present time
words.example: She's an expert in contemporary art.

words.definition: Known or talked about by many people; famous
words.example: She is renowned for her contributions to science.

words.definition: Important; famous; projecting from something
words.example: She played a prominent role in the campaign.

words.definition: The treatment of an issue by the media
words.example: The newspaper gave extensive coverage to the story.

words.definition: A heading at the top of an article or page in a newspaper
words.example: The scandal made headlines around the world.

words.definition: The activity or profession of writing for newspapers or broadcasting news
words.example: She studied journalism at university.

words.definition: The suppression or prohibition of speech or writing deemed unacceptable
words.example: Many countries practise censorship of the media.

words.definition: Information used to promote a political cause or point of view
words.example: The film was dismissed as government propaganda.

words.definition: A fact or situation that is observed to exist or happen
words.example: Social media is a relatively new phenomenon.

words.definition: The transmission of customs or beliefs from generation to generation
words.example: It's a tradition to eat turkey at Christmas.

words.definition: A religious or solemn ceremony consisting of a series of actions
words.example: The tribe performs ancient rituals.

words.definition: A traditional and widely accepted way of behaving specific to a society
words.example: It is the custom to shake hands when you meet someone.

words.definition: The action of preserving something
words.example: The preservation of historic buildings is important.

words.definition: An organised course of action to achieve a goal
words.example: They launched a campaign to raise awareness.

words.definition: The action or process of reforming an institution or practice
words.example: The government has promised educational reform.

words.definition: Laws, considered collectively
words.example: New legislation on data protection was introduced.

words.definition: To put a decision or plan into effect
words.example: The company will implement the new policy next month.

words.definition: To act in accordance with a wish or command
words.example: All companies must comply with safety regulations.

words.definition: To compel observance of a law or rule
words.example: It's the police's job to enforce the law.

words.definition: To become apparent or prominent
words.example: New evidence has emerged in the case.

words.definition: To prove more powerful; to be widespread in a particular area
words.example: Common sense will prevail in the end.

words.definition: To cause to continue for an extended period or without interruption
words.example: The economy cannot sustain this level of growth.

words.definition: To make a marked change in form, nature, or appearance
words.example: Technology has transformed the way we work.

words.definition: Involving or causing a complete or dramatic change
words.example: The invention was revolutionary for its time.

words.definition: Happening or developing gradually over a period of time
words.example: The school has a progressive approach to education.

words.definition: Following traditional or generally accepted beliefs
words.example: His views are fairly orthodox on most issues.

words.definition: Of minor importance; at the edge or periphery
words.example: The difference in price is marginal.

words.definition: Existing or occurring at or on the surface; not thorough or deep
words.example: His knowledge of the subject is rather superficial.

words.definition: Of little value or importance
words.example: Don't waste time on trivial matters.

words.definition: An act or course of action to which a person is morally or legally bound
words.example: Parents have an obligation to care for their children.

words.definition: A special right or advantage granted to a person or group
words.example: Education is a privilege, not a right.

words.definition: The fact of being responsible for decisions and able to explain them
words.example: There needs to be greater accountability in government.

words.definition: The condition of being open and honest; lack of secrecy
words.example: The company has committed to greater transparency.

words.definition: The state of being aware of and responsive to one's surroundings
words.example: Environmental consciousness is growing.

words.definition: Knowledge or perception of a situation or fact
words.example: The campaign raised awareness of the issue.

words.definition: An event, action, or object that clearly shows or embodies something
words.example: The riots were a manifestation of public anger.

words.definition: An inclination towards a particular characteristic or type of behaviour
words.example: There's a tendency for prices to rise before Christmas.

words.definition: An area of activity, interest, or expertise
words.example: She works in the sphere of international relations.

words.definition: A specified sphere of activity or knowledge
words.example: Physics is outside my domain of expertise.

words.definition: A field or domain of activity or interest
words.example: This question belongs in the realm of philosophy.

words.definition: To cite or appeal to someone or something as an authority
words.example: She invoked her right to remain silent.

words.definition: To involve something as a necessary or inevitable part or consequence
words.example: The job entails a lot of travelling.

words.definition: To consist of; to be made up of
words.example: The committee comprises representatives from all departments.

words.definition: To be a part of a whole; to form or compose
words.example: Women constitute 40% of the workforce.

words.definition: To grow or develop in a healthy or vigorous way
words.example: The arts flourished during this period.

words.definition: In spite of that; nevertheless
words.example: The weather was bad; nonetheless, we enjoyed ourselves.

words.definition: As a further matter; besides
words.example: The plan is expensive; moreover, it's impractical.

words.definition: By that means; as a result of that
words.example: He increased investment, thereby creating more jobs.

words.definition: By which; through which
words.example: We need a system whereby information can be shared.

words.definition: A system of ideas and ideals forming the basis of a political theory
words.example: The party's ideology is based on social equality.

words.definition: To make use of a situation in a way that is unfair or unethical
words.example: Companies should not exploit their workers.

words.definition: To work jointly on an activity or project
words.example: Scientists from different countries collaborated on the research.

words.definition: To make an action or process easier
words.example: Technology can facilitate communication across distances.

words.definition: To estimate something to be smaller or less important than it really is
words.example: Don't underestimate the difficulty of the task.

words.definition: To give a misleading account or impression; to pull or twist out of shape
words.example: The media distorted the facts of the case.

words.definition: To control or influence someone or something cleverly or unscrupulously
words.example: He tried to manipulate public opinion.

words.definition: A claim that someone has done something illegal or wrong, without proof
words.example: The politician denied all allegations of corruption.
